StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Genome Wide Association Study of Alopecia Areata

Person.Organization: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCESNATIONAL ALOPECIA AREATA FOUNDATIONNORTH AMERICAN HAIR RESEARCH SOCIETY

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The data used for the analyses described in this paper were obtained from the database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP), at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gap. Genotype and phenotype data for the Genome-Wide Association Study of Alopecia Areata (dbGaP accession number phs000586.v1.p1) were provided by Angela M. Christiano, Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. Funding support for the original study was provided by the National Institutes of Health, and by other sources detailed in Nature 2010 Jul 1;466(7302):113-7. Genome-wide association study in alopecia areata implicates both innate and adaptive immunity. Petukhova L, Duvic M, Hordinsky M, Norris D, Price V, Shimomura Y, Kim H, Singh P, Lee A, Chen WV, Meyer KC, Paus R, Jahoda CA, Amos CI, Gregersen PK, Christiano AM.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution did not respond within six months)

ConsentGroup.title: Disease-Specific (Alopecia areata, MDS, RD)
ConsentGroup.name: DS-AA-MDS-RD
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction:
Use of the data must be related to Alopecia areata and related disorders. Use of the data includes methods development research (e.g., development of software or algorithms).
This dataset may be used for the study of alopecia areata and other autoimmune conditions associated with alopecia areata, including autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes, vitiligo, rheumatoid arthritis, and celiac disease. Other appropriate use of data could include methodological development, study of fundamental biological processes that are known or suspected to underlie autoimmune diseases, and construction of analytic tools for end users.
